title: Sketch of the Peacock Room

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of graphite (recto) on cream wove paper with printed text in black ink (verso).

medium_display: Graphite (recto) on cream wove paper with printed text in black ink (verso)
inscriptions: Inscribed recto, lower left to lower right, below image, along margin, in dark brown-black ink by A. Ludovici: "Whistler's sketch of the Peacock Room.  to give me an idea of it. done at Fracato's. [sic]  17th Dec - 1898 - / A. Ludovici"; inscribed verso, lower  center, in graphite: "No 123 of London Catalogue -- page 122. / Lent by the artist Ludovici  (1898)" (upside down); inscribed verso, lower right, in graphite: "FHO"; inscribed verso, lower left, in graphite: "a 50081"; inscribed verso, lower left, in graphite: "R. 10445"; inscribed verso, center top, in graphite: "lc / (illegible); inscribed verso, upper left, in graphite: £110" (upside down)
publication_history:
Elisabeth Luther Cary, The Works of James McNeill Whistler (New York, 1907), p. 225, no. 465.

W. McC. McK., “Drawings from the Charles Deering Collection," Bulletin of the Art Institute of Chicago 22:5 (May 1928), p. 66. 

Andrew McLaren Young, Margaret F. MacDonald, Robin Spencer, Hamish Miles, The Paintings of James McNeill Whistler (New Haven, 1980), p. 104, under no. 178.

Margaret F. MacDonald, James McNeill Whistler: Drawings, Pastels, and Watercolours: A Catalogue Raisonné (New Haven, 1995), p. 567, no. 1581 (ill.).

Linda Merrill, The Peacock Room: A Cultural Biography (Washington, D.C., New Haven, and London, 1998), pp. 298-99, fig. 7.4 (ill.).
exhibition_history:
London, New Gallery, "Memorial Exhibition of the Works of the Late James McNeill Whistler," Feb. 22-Apr. 15, 1905, p. 122, cat. 123.

Art Institute of Chicago, “Drawings from the Charles Deering Collection,” May 1-July 1, 1928.
provenance_text: The artist to Albert Ludovici, 1898-at least 1905 [inscription; London 1905].  Charles Deering (1852–1927), Chicago [stamp (Lugt 516) verso, lower right, in blue]; by descent to his daughters, Mrs. Chauncey McCormick (née Marion Deering; 1886–1965), Chicago and Mrs. Richard Ely Danielson (née Barbara Deering; 1885–1957), Chicago; given to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1927.
section_titles: Cat. 48 Sketch of the Peacock Room, 1898
